title: On $r$-Equichromatic Lines with few points in $\mathbb{C}^2$
abstract:
Let $P$ be a set of $n$ green and $n - k$ red points in $\mathbb{C}^2$. A
line determined by $i$ green and $j$ red points such that $i + j \ge 2$ and $|i
- j| \le r$ is called \emph{r-equichromatic}. We establish lower bounds for
$1$-equichromatic and $2$-equichromatic lines. In particular, we show that if
at most $2n-k-2$ points of $P$ are collinear, then the number of
$1$-equichromatic lines passing through at most six points is at least
$\frac{1}{4}(6n-k(k+3))$, and if at most $\frac{2}{3}(2n - k)$ points of $P$
are collinear, then the number of $2$-equichromatic lines passing through at
most four points is at least $\frac{1}{6}(10n - k(k + 5))$.
